paper_title: When the Levee Breaks: Black Migration and Economic Development in the American South

baseline_groups.label: Flood impact on Black share of population

claim_object.outcome_concept: Log fraction Black population in county
claim_object.treatment_concept: Flood intensity (share of county flooded in 1927 Mississippi flood) interacted with post-flood year dummies
claim_object.estimand_concept: Dynamic ATT path: effect of flood exposure on Black population share at each post-flood decade
claim_object.target_population: Counties in Southern US states bordering the Mississippi flood zone (balanced panel, >=10% Black and >=15% cotton in 1920)

constraints.controls_count_note: RefTable 1 step 1 uses lagged DV only (~15 vars for G1: 3 lag orders x 5 year interactions). Table 2 col 1 (geography+lags) has ~36. Table 2 col 2 (+New Deal) has ~61. RefTable 1 step 7 (full kitchen sink with tenancy/mfg/plantation/propensity) is the maximum at ~80. The min/max here span the full revealed range across RefTable progression steps.
constraints.controls_mandatory_note: No mandatory controls; even the lagged DV can be dropped (rc/controls/sets/none is a stress test below the revealed minimum).
constraints.linked_adjustment_note: Not a bundled estimator; single-equation TWFE
constraints.max_fe_note: county + state-by-year; paper does not vary FE structure

rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/sets/none: Stress test: FE only, no time-varying controls. Below revealed minimum but standard stress test.
rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/progression/geography_only: Geography block only (no lagged DV). Not a revealed RefTable step (all RefTable steps include lagged DV), but included as stress test. Renamed from 'geography' for clarity.
rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/progression/geography_lags_t: RefTable step 3. Tenancy block = lag*_lnfarms_nonwhite_t_*, mfg block = lag*_lnmfgestab_*, lag*_lnmfgavewages_*.
rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/progression/geography_lags_n: RefTable step 5. Adds plantation_* year-interacted dummies.
rc_spec_notes.loo_block_base_spec: LOO blocks computed relative to Table 2 col 2 baseline (geography + lags + New Deal).
rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/loo_block/drop_tenancy_mfg: Added: drop tenancy/mfg block from RefTable step 6/7 spec.
rc_spec_notes.pre1960_removed: rc/sample/time/pre1960_only removed from G1: G1 has decadal observations only (1930,1940,1950,1960,1970), so no 1964 to drop. 'pre1960_only' for G1 = 'drop_1970', already covered.

budgets.notes: Full enumeration feasible since controls progression is block-based (not combinatorial variable-level subsets)

sampling.notes: Control variations are block-based progressions (revealed by RefTables 1-3); no variable-level combinatorial subset search needed

diagnostics_plan.description: Event study coefficients for pre-flood periods (1900, 1910, 1920 dummies) from Figure 3 specification; visual pre-trends check
Joint F-test of pre-flood year dummies = 0 for each specification

baseline_groups.label: Flood impact on agricultural capital intensity

claim_object.outcome_concept: Log value of farm equipment per county (mechanization/capital intensity)
claim_object.treatment_concept: Flood intensity (share of county flooded in 1927 Mississippi flood) interacted with post-flood year dummies
claim_object.estimand_concept: Dynamic ATT path: effect of flood exposure on agricultural capital at each post-flood census year
claim_object.target_population: Counties in Southern US states bordering the Mississippi flood zone (balanced panel, >=10% Black and >=15% cotton in 1920)
claim_object.direction_expectation: Positive (labor outflow induced capital substitution toward mechanization)

constraints.controls_count_note: RefTable 2 step 1 uses lagged DV only (~20 vars for G2: 4 lag orders x ~5 year interactions). Table 4 col 3 (geography+lags) has ~42. Table 4 col 4 (+New Deal) has ~67. RefTable 2 step 7 (full kitchen sink) is the maximum at ~90. G2 has more periods (9 post-treatment) than G1 (5), so year-interacted controls have more variables.
constraints.linked_adjustment_note: Not a bundled estimator; single-equation TWFE
constraints.max_fe_note: county + state-by-year; paper does not vary FE structure

rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/sets/none: Stress test: FE only, no time-varying controls.
rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/progression/geography_only: Geography block only (no lagged DV). Not a revealed RefTable step, included as stress test.
rc_spec_notes.loo_block_base_spec: LOO blocks computed relative to Table 4 col 4 baseline (geography + lags + New Deal).
rc_spec_notes.rc/controls/loo_block/drop_tenancy_mfg: Added: drop tenancy/mfg block from RefTable step 6/7 spec.
rc_spec_notes.rc/sample/time/pre1960_only: G2 has intercensus observations (1964); pre1960_only drops 1960, 1964, and 1970, keeping 1930-1954. This is a meaningful time-window restriction for G2.

budgets.notes: Same block-based structure as G1; full enumeration feasible. Slightly higher budget than G1 because G2 retains pre1960_only spec.

diagnostics_plan.description: Event study coefficients for pre-flood periods from Figure 4 specification
Joint F-test of pre-flood year dummies = 0

controls.description: Paper reveals 7 control-set progressions across RefTables 1-3: (1) lagged DV only, (2) lagged DV + geography, (3) lagged DV + geography + tenancy/mfg, (4) lagged DV + geography + New Deal, (5) lagged DV + geography + New Deal + plantation, (6) lagged DV + geography + New Deal + tenancy/mfg, (7) lagged DV + geography + New Deal + tenancy/mfg + propensity score. NOTE: all 7 steps include lagged DV; geography-only (without lags) is NOT a revealed step.
blocks_identified: geography (crop suitability x year + distance to MS x year + coordinates x year + ruggedness x year)
lagged dependent variables (outcome-specific: lag2-4 for G1 labor, lag1-4 for G2 capital)
New Deal spending controls (5 per-capita spending measures x year)
tenancy/manufacturing (lagged nonwhite farm tenancy share x year + lagged mfg establishments x year + lagged mfg wages x year)
propensity score (prop_plant_flstate_1* -- propensity for plantation status in flood states)

treatment_definition.description: Paper reveals 3 flood intensity measures: (1) baseline flood_intensity = share of county flooded, (2) flood_intensity_2 = Red Cross flooded acres/county area, (3) flood_intensity_3 = Red Cross affected population/total population

inference.description: Paper uses county-clustered SE as baseline, and explicitly computes Conley spatial HAC SE at 50mi, 100mi, and 200mi cutoffs

sample.description: Main sample restricted to counties with >=10% Black and >=15% cotton; Tables 6-7 use alternative samples (southern rivers, non-flooded counties) as falsification/validation

outcomes.description: Paper examines multiple outcomes across Tables 2, 4, 5: labor (frac_black, population_black, population), capital (equipment, tractors, mules/horses, farm size), farmland (farmland acres, land/building values). Additional tables include crop yields, crop value per capita.
outcomes.note: Multiple outcomes are different baseline groups for the core claim (labor=G1, capital=G2). Other outcomes are exploration.

weights.description: All regressions use analytic weights (county_w = county area in 1920). Unweighted is not shown but is a natural RC.

fixed_effects.description: All panel regressions use county FE (absorbed) + state-by-year FE. No variation in FE structure is revealed.

axes_not_revealed_but_feasible.fe_variations: Dropping state-by-year FE to year FE only; this is a meaningful RC but changes identifying variation substantially
axes_not_revealed_but_feasible.alternative_estimators: Modern heterogeneity-robust DiD estimators (e.g., Sun-Abraham, Callaway-Santanna) are not applicable because treatment timing is not staggered -- all treatment occurs simultaneously in 1927 with continuous intensity
axes_not_revealed_but_feasible.sample_restrictions: Relaxing the 10% Black or 15% cotton sample restrictions could change the target population

design_notes.treatment_timing: The 1927 Mississippi flood is a single event; all treatment occurs simultaneously. This is NOT staggered adoption. flood_intensity is continuous (share of county flooded), not binary.
design_notes.panel_structure: Balanced panel of ~163 counties observed at census years: 1900, 1910, 1920, 1925, 1930, 1935, 1940, 1945, 1950, 1954, 1960, 1964, 1970 (13 periods). Post-treatment periods for Table 2 labor outcomes: 1930-1970 (5 decadal periods). Post-treatment for Table 4 capital outcomes: 1930-1970 with additional 5-year intercensus periods (9 periods).
design_notes.identification: Continuous-treatment DiD: county FE absorb time-invariant county heterogeneity; state-by-year FE absorb state-level aggregate shocks. Treatment = flood_intensity (continuous) interacted with post-flood year dummies. Key identifying assumption: parallel trends in outcomes across counties with different flood intensity, conditional on controls.
design_notes.modern_did_note: Because treatment is continuous intensity from a single event (not staggered binary adoption), modern staggered-DiD estimators (Callaway-Santanna, Sun-Abraham, Borusyak imputation) are NOT directly applicable. The relevant concern is whether TWFE with continuous treatment and multiple post-periods produces well-defined causal parameters, but this is the standard specification in the literature.
design_notes.conley_se_note: The paper explicitly computes Conley spatial HAC standard errors at 50mi, 100mi, and 200mi cutoffs as a robustness check. These are important because counties near the Mississippi River may have spatially correlated shocks.
design_notes.dataset_note: Main tables (Table 2, 4, 5) use preanalysis_post1930.dta (post-treatment panel only). RefTables 1-3 use preanalysis.dta (full panel including pre-treatment years), but because treatment variables f_int_* are zero before 1930, the treatment coefficient estimates are numerically equivalent. The Conley SE computation uses period-by-period first-differenced regressions. Event study figures (Figures 3-4) use preanalysis.dta with pre-treatment year dummies included.
design_notes.lagged_dv_note: G1 (labor outcomes) uses lag2-lag4 of the DV (no lag1), while G2 (capital outcomes) uses lag1-lag4. This is because Table 2 labor data has decadal observations (so lag1 = immediate pre-period = reference) while Table 4 capital data has 5-year intercensus observations. The lagged DV block must be outcome-specific.
design_notes.tenancy_mfg_block_note: The tenancy/manufacturing block in RefTables consists of lagged versions of these variables interacted with year: lag*_lnfarms_nonwhite_t_* (nonwhite farm tenancy share), lag*_lnmfgestab_* (manufacturing establishments), lag*_lnmfgavewages_* (manufacturing average wages). These are time-varying economic controls that could be endogenous to the flood.
